algorithms.imageProcessing.transform

Class Triangulation

  • java.lang.Object
    • algorithms.imageProcessing.transform.Triangulation

  • public class Triangulation
extends java.lang.Object
    given correspondence between two images and intrinsic and extrinsic camera parameters, determine the real world position. useful reading: 
     http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~16385/s17/Slides/11.4_Triangulation.pdf
 add other references here
    TODO: construct a method that might be better placed in reconstruction: given camera intrinsic parameters and 2-view correspondences: first calculate the essential matrix, then extract the cameras extrinsic parameters from them, then use triangulation to get the WCS coordinates.
    Author:
    nichole

    • Method Detail

      • calculateWCSPoint

        public static double[] calculateWCSPoint(double[][] k1,
                                         double[][] r1,
                                         double[] t1,
                                         double[][] k2,
                                         double[][] r2,
                                         double[] t2,
                                         double[][] x1,
                                         double[][] x2)
        given the intrinsic and extrinsic camera matrices for 2 images and given the matching correspondence of points between the 2 images, calculate the real world coordinate of the observations. 
         following http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~16385/s17/Slides/11.4_Triangulation.pdf
        Parameters:
        k1 - intrinsic camera matrix for image 1 in units of pixels.
        r1 - the rotation matrix for the extrinsic camera matrix for image 1.
        t1 - the translation vector for the extrinsic camera matrix for image 1.
        k2 - intrinsic camera matrix for image 2 in units of pixels.
        r2 - the rotation matrix for the extrinsic camera matrix for image 2.
        t2 - the translation vector for the extrinsic camera matrix for image 2.
        x1 - the image 1 set of correspondence points. format is 3 x N where N is the number of points. all points are observations of real world point X.
        x2 - the image 2 set of correspondence points. format is 3 x N where N is the number of points. . all points are observations of real world point X.
        Returns:
        the point coordinates in world coordinate reference frame

      • calculateWCSPoint

        public static double[] calculateWCSPoint(Camera.CameraParameters camera1,
                                         Camera.CameraParameters camera2,
                                         double[][] x1,
                                         double[][] x2)
        given the camera matrix as intrinsic and extrinsic matrices for 2 images and given the matching correspondence of points between the 2 images, calculate the real world coordinate of the observations. 
         following http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~16385/s17/Slides/11.4_Triangulation.pdf
 add references here
        Parameters:
        camera1 - camera matrix for image 1 in units of pixels containing intrinsic and extrinsic parameters. the size is 3X4.
        camera2 - camera matrix for image 2 in units of pixels containing extrinsic parameters. the size is 3X4.
        x1 - the image 1 set of measurements of real world point X. The corresponding measurements of the same point in image 2 are in x2. format is 3 x N where N is the number of measurements.
        x2 - the image 2 set of measurements of real world point X. The corresponding measurements of the same point in image 1 are in x1. format is 3 x N where N is the number of measurements.
        Returns:
        the point coordinates in world coordinate reference frame

      • calculateWCSPoint

        public static double[] calculateWCSPoint(Camera.CameraProjection camera1,
                                         Camera.CameraProjection camera2,
                                         double[][] x1,
                                         double[][] x2)
        not yet tested. given the camera projection matrix as intrinsic times extrinsic matrices for 2 images and given the matching correspondence of points between the 2 images, calculate the real world coordinate of the observations. 
         following http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~16385/s17/Slides/11.4_Triangulation.pdf
 add references here
        Parameters:
        camera1 - camera matrix for image 1 in units of pixels containing extrinsic parameters. the size is 3X4.
        camera2 - camera matrix for image 2 in units of pixels containing extrinsic parameters. the size is 3X4.
        x1 - the image 1 set of measurements of 1 real world point X. The corresponding measurements of the same point in image 2 are in x2. format is 3 x N where N is the number of measurements.
        x2 - the image 2 set of measurements of 1 real world point X. The corresponding measurements of the same point in image 1 are in x1. format is 3 x N where N is the number of measurements.

      • calculateWCSPoint

        public static double[] calculateWCSPoint(double[][] camera1,
                                         double[][] camera2,
                                         double[][] x1,
                                         double[][] x2)
        not yet tested. given the camera projection matrix as intrinsic times extrinsic matrices for 2 images and given the matching correspondence of points between the 2 images, calculate the real world coordinate of the observations. 
         following http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~16385/s17/Slides/11.4_Triangulation.pdf
        Parameters:
        camera1 - camera matrix for image 1 in units of pixels containing extrinsic parameters. the size is 3X4.
        camera2 - camera matrix for image 2 in units of pixels containing extrinsic parameters. the size is 3X4.
        x1 - the image 1 set of measurements of 1 real world point X. The corresponding measurements of the same point in image 2 are in x2. format is 3 x N where N is the number of measurements. If the data are perfect, only need 1 pair of correspondence (i.e. x1[*,0] and x2[*,0]), If the data are not perfect, need more than 1 pair for best fit.
        x2 - the image 2 set of measurements of 1 real world point X. The corresponding measurements of the same point in image 1 are in x1. format is 3 x N where N is the number of measurements.
        Returns:
        the 3D coordinate of the point in world scene. note that the entire array can be normalized by the last element.
